structured_info.title_cn: 共享专用自动驾驶卡车车道策略提升混合高速公路交通的可持续性和效率
structured_info.title_en: A shared strategy of dedicated autonomous truck lanes for enhancing sustainability and efficiency in mixed freeway traffic
structured_info.abstract: This paper presents the shared dedicated lane (SDL) strategy, designed to optimize dedicated lane utilization and enhance traffic flow in mixed environments with connected automated trucks (CATs) and human-driven vehicles (HDVs). The strategy consists of two components: the Platoon Optimal Formation (POF) model, which minimizes fuel consumption for CATs by determining the most efficient platoon formations, and the Two-Lane Cellular Automaton (TCA) model, which simulates vehicle movements, introduces lane-changing rules, and establishes CAT priority conditions to ensure efficient SDL utilization by HDVs. Numerical experiments were conducted on a multi-lane freeway to evaluate the SDL strategy under various traffic scenarios with different CAT demand ratios. The results show that the SDL strategy outperforms traditional approaches by improving traffic flow, fuel efficiency, and overall performance in mixed conditions. Specifically, it reduces fuel consumption by up to 10% under high CAT demand ratios and alleviates congestion while increasing HDV speeds during low CAT demand ratios.
structured_info.methodology: The paper proposes a shared dedicated lane (SDL) strategy consisting of two main components: the Platoon Optimal Formation (POF) model for optimizing CAT platoon formations to minimize fuel consumption, and the Two-Lane Cellular Automaton (TCA) model for simulating vehicle movements and lane-changing behaviors. The methodology involves numerical experiments on a multi-lane freeway under various traffic scenarios.
structured_info.conclusion: The SDL strategy significantly reduces fuel consumption for CATs across all demand ratios, alleviates congestion, and enhances HDV speeds under low CAT demand ratios. It outperforms traditional dedicated lane strategies by improving both traffic efficiency and sustainability in mixed traffic environments.

analysis.Overview: The paper presents a shared dedicated lane (SDL) strategy for mixed traffic environments with connected automated trucks (CATs) and human-driven vehicles (HDVs). The strategy aims to optimize lane utilization and improve traffic flow through platoon formation optimization and lane-changing rules.
Background_and_Motivation: The research addresses the challenge of inefficient road resource utilization in mixed traffic scenarios where autonomous and human-driven vehicles coexist.
The motivation stems from the need to improve fuel efficiency and traffic flow in environments with low penetration rates of connected automated vehicles.
The authors highlight the negative impact of traditional dedicated lane strategies at low CAV market penetration rates and propose SDL as a solution.
The problem is framed within the broader challenge of sustainable transportation and efficient traffic management in the transition period towards full automation.
The paper contributes to transportation engineering, specifically in traffic management and autonomous vehicle systems.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Shared Dedicated Lane (SDL): A strategy allowing HDVs to utilize underused CAT-dedicated lanes under specific conditions.
Platoon Optimal Formation (POF): A model to determine fuel-efficient platoon configurations for CATs.
Two-Lane Cellular Automaton (TCA): A simulation model for vehicle movements and lane-changing behaviors.
The concepts are interrelated through the SDL framework, where POF optimizes platoons while TCA manages lane utilization.
Key assumptions include all vehicles being connected, negligible control delays for CATs, and human drivers not being influenced by the system.
The paper contributes a novel lane management strategy and optimization models to the field of intelligent transportation systems.
Methodology: The core methods include the POF nonlinear integer programming model for platoon optimization and the TCA model for traffic simulation.
The methodology is novel in combining platoon optimization with lane-sharing strategies, and its applicability is demonstrated through numerical experiments.
Simulation data includes various traffic demand scenarios (2500-4000 veh/h) and CAT demand ratios (0.1-0.9).
Experimental design includes comparison with traditional strategies and evaluation through multiple performance metrics.
The research follows a computational modeling paradigm common in transportation engineering.
Results: Fuel consumption reduced by up to 18% under high CAT demand ratios.
Congestion alleviated and HDV speeds increased during low CAT demand ratios.
Results show consistent performance improvements across different traffic scenarios, demonstrating reliability.
Argumentation_and_Logic: The argument progresses from problem identification to solution proposal, then to experimental validation.
Key steps include: 1) Demonstrating limitations of current approaches, 2) Proposing SDL strategy, 3) Developing models, 4) Experimental validation.
Strengths include comprehensive experimental validation; potential weakness is the simplified assumptions about vehicle connectivity.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Innovative combination of platoon optimization and lane-sharing strategies.
Comprehensive performance evaluation across multiple metrics.
Limitations include simplified assumptions about perfect connectivity and control delays.
The computational modeling approach may not capture all real-world complexities.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: The paper positions itself within ongoing discourse about autonomous vehicle integration and traffic management.
Technical terminology is used precisely, with clear definitions of key concepts.
Citations establish authority by referencing foundational work in CAV research and traffic modeling.
Conclusions_and_Implications: The SDL strategy effectively improves both sustainability and efficiency in mixed traffic.
Future work should address more complex road configurations and additional vehicle types.
